floor: I know there are some hard-working people with integrity on that side. Will any of them stand up, show some independence, and say no to the Prime Minister and no to the House leader, who has completely botched this for all of you?

floor: She has seen a lot of the stuff that has taken place here.

floor: Even the most out-of-touch Hollywood celebrity would blush at this type of spending, and 17 hundred bucks to feed a family of five on a three hour flight.

floor: They are shutting down debate, they are ramming through legislation, and we have a Prime Minister who does not want to answer questions directly on his ethical lapses.

floor: Last week it was revealed that the Prime Minister also used the non-partisan Privy Council Office and its staff to support those same campaign events.

floor: This has been brought into play by the bill I submitted in the 41st Parliament, unanimously supported in the House and the Senate, and continues to be strongly supported by members on all sides of this House.

floor: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak a bit about the agenda we have for seniors, a very strong agenda, and not only for this generation of seniors, many of whom are being taken out of poverty through the increase in the guaranteed income supplement and the lowering of the age of eligibility to 65 years—100,000 seniors will not need to enter into severe poverty—but also through the enhancement of the Canada pension plan, which is going to take 300,000 future seniors out of income vulnerability.

floor: Mr. Speaker, as the member opposite well knows, I spend a tremendous amount of time working hard for Canadians right across the country, meeting with them, meeting with crowds, meeting with individuals, listening to consumer groups, listening to small businesses, engaging with Canadians right across the country, and I will continue to do so, as will the members of our cabinet.

floor: Will the minister please tell Canadians exactly how many Liberal infrastructure projects have actual shovels in the ground and are under construction?

floor: Therefore, why do the Liberals still sanction the use of information obtained through torture?

floor: Instead of giving him a concrete promise to address his concerns, the Liberals instead said they would set up yet another consultative process to study the issue.

floor: There is no definitive medical test for thalidomide exposure.

floor: Le gouvernement fédéral, avec les provinces et les territoires du Canada, a reconnu, à Vancouver, que nous devions avoir un plan ambitieux pour respecter nos obligations internationales aujourd'hui et dans l'avenir.

Speaker: Mr. Mark Strahl (Chilliwack—Hope, CPC)

floor: Mr. Speaker, the Liberals have now confirmed that they are planning to impose a made-in-Ottawa carbon tax on all Canadians, no matter where they live and no matter if their province already has a carbon tax.

floor: Why are the Liberals so intent on threatening British Columbia families with their made-in-Ottawa, job-killing carbon tax?

english: Mr. Speaker, unlike the party opposite, we understand that the environment and the economy go together.
floor: Mr. Speaker, unlike the party opposite, we understand that the environment and the economy go together.

floor: I am very proud that more than 140 members of Parliament on this side of the House have either had, or will have in a very short while, town halls.

floor: First the Liberals charged entry into their town halls, then the justice minister turned away over 30 people from her meeting, and now the Liberals are making shady deals with third parties to make sunny ways electoral ads, despite the claims we are hearing today.

floor: Je veux encourager le Parti conservateur à participer, avec les autres partis et avec le Parti libéral, aux consultations partout au Canada pour améliorer notre système.

Speaker: Hon. Rob Nicholson (Niagara Falls, CPC)

floor: It is also the fair thing to do.

floor: No decision has been made, but we are confident that we will appoint a diverse, functionally bilingual, high-calibre jurist to the Supreme Court of Canada.

floor: We are going to be going in with eyes wide open, making sure that we have all the necessary information to allow the military to do its work, as well as the Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Minister of International Development.

floor: Est-ce cela, le Canada des libéraux?

floor: Nous savons cela, mais est-ce qu'il y aura enfin une entente pour aider l'économie de toutes les provinces du pays?

floor: Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to inform the House that today the parliament of Sweden rejected the same kind of motion by a vote of 268 to 43.

floor: Mr. Speaker, Canada used to be a moral leader.

floor: Liberals have promised to implement the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, which means prior and informed consent from indigenous peoples on all decisions that affect them.

floor: Why are Liberals moving ahead with the damaging TPP without meaningful consultations with indigenous peoples in Canada?

floor: Will the minister take responsibility for her office, and end this discriminatory and dangerous practice?

floor: The NIHB program covers over $1 billion in health benefits for first nations and Inuit every year.

floor: It is important that there be a competitive market in credit card fees so consumers can be well treated.

floor: The applications that are made by police authorities need to be proportionate, they need to be justified on the grounds of the subject matter under investigation.

floor: We further enforce international requirements on foreign vessels operating in Canada through the port state control program.

floor: Comme le disait d'ailleurs si bien ce prestigieux et très émérite personnage s'il en est un, le ministre des Affaires étrangères, c'est inévitable.

floor: Today, we are risk-managing a gap between our NORAD commitments and our NATO commitments, in part because we inherited a bit of a mess from the previous government.

english: Nearly 99% of pharmacy claims and 90% of the dental claims were approved, and more than 90% of the pharmacy claims were approved instantly at the point of the sale.
floor: Nearly 99% of pharmacy claims and 90% of the dental claims were approved, and more than 90% of the pharmacy claims were approved instantly at the point of the sale.

Speaker: Mr. Sean Casey (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada, Lib.)
english: Mr. Speaker, we believe that we have struck the right balance in Bill C-14 between protecting the vulnerable and the conscience rights of health care professionals, and also providing access to medical assistance in dying and protecting personal autonomy.
floor: Mr. Speaker, we believe that we have struck the right balance in Bill C-14 between protecting the vulnerable and the conscience rights of health care professionals, and also providing access to medical assistance in dying and protecting personal autonomy.

Speaker: Mr. Serge Cormier (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard, Lib.)

floor: Il y a eu une très bonne participation lors des réunions du comité.

Speaker: Mr. Serge Cormier (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard, Lib.)
english: We are waiting for the report in order to make a decision.
floor: Nous attendrons le rapport pour prendre une décision par la suite.

Speaker: Hon. John McKay (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence, Lib.)

floor: Therefore, the question is based upon gossip and rumour, and wherever else the hon. member gets his source of information.

floor: The TRC's call to action number 43 calls on the government to do the same.

floor: Most in my riding are patiently waiting for a positive decision by the Liberals on Pacific Northwest LNG, a decision that would address the growing Liberal deficit by providing billions in revenue.

floor: What we have done is that when a veteran believes his claim has been incorrectly assessed, we have set up an independent review process, the Veterans Review and Appeal Board.

Speaker: Mr. Blake Richards (Banff—Airdrie, CPC)
english: Politicians making the decision, or will the minister actually drop the talking points and leave this decision directly in the hands of Canadians through a referendum?
floor: Politicians making the decision, or will the minister actually drop the talking points and leave this decision directly in the hands of Canadians through a referendum?

floor: Mr. Speaker, the men and women of the Canadian Coast Guard work hard to protect Canadians and the bodies of water from coast to coast to coast.

floor: We think a better idea is to have a transparent process, with predictable timelines and ways in which Canadians can let government know what they think is in the national interest, after which the government will decide.

floor: In the meantime, the member knows that first nation governments will continue their long-standing reporting of audited statements to our department, including chiefs' and councillors' salaries, and any first nation member can get that information from our department.

english: Mr. Speaker, today the Commissioner of Official Languages tabled a scathing report on Air Canada.
floor: Monsieur le Président, le commissaire aux langues officielles a déposé aujourd'hui un rapport accablant sur Air Canada.

english: Will the Liberals commit today to taking action to resolve this problem once and for all?
floor: Les libéraux peuvent-ils s'engager aujourd'hui à agir pour régler une fois pour toutes ce problème?

floor: The city of Toronto will receive $840 million in phase one, which can include active transportation, as we currently develop our second term, phase two, long-term plan.

floor: The expenditures the member is referring to were to provide office space for the minister and the deputy minister and a space for all of our staff members, as well as to consolidate them on one floor.

Speaker: Hon. Mélanie Joly (Minister of Canadian Heritage, Lib.)

floor: Monsieur le Président, je tiens à rassurer mon collègue quant à l'importance pour le gouvernement de nos deux langues officielles.

Speaker: L’hon. Mélanie Joly (ministre du Patrimoine canadien, Lib.)
english: That is why I will work with my colleague, the Minister of Transport, on this issue, to ensure that the recommendations of the Commissioner of Official Languages will be examined.
floor: Monsieur le Président, je tiens à rassurer mon collègue quant à l'importance pour le gouvernement de nos deux langues officielles.

Speaker: Mr. Alain Rayes (Richmond—Arthabaska, CPC)
english: The real question is this: will the Liberals try to change the rules of democracy to their advantage or are they trying out an agreement with the NDP rather than consulting Canadians directly through a referendum?
floor: La vraie question est la suivante: vont-ils essayer de changer les règles de la démocratie à leur avantage, ou tentent-ils une entente libérale-néo-démocrate au lieu de consulter directement tous les Canadiens et Canadiennes par référendum?

floor: Monsieur le Président, comme je viens de le dire, nous sommes conscients des préoccupations de l'industrie quant à l'utilisation du lait diafiltré dans la fabrication du fromage.

floor: Mr. Speaker, days ago I met, along with the Minister of Sport and Persons with Disabilities, with the Elections Canada advisory group on persons with disabilities.

floor: Our job is to ensure that the voices of the marginalized are included in this conversation.

floor: In my riding of Kingston and the Islands two prison farms were closed in Collins Bay and Joyceville, without proper consultation of the public and to widespread concern from the public.

floor: I thank the member for Kingston and the Islands for contributing to that goal.

floor: Mr. Speaker, the Ethics Commissioner has ruled that the new Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard cannot have any dealings with the Irving family.

floor: C'est ce que le ministre s'est engagé à faire, et c'est ce qu'il fera à l'avenir.

floor: La commissaire a recommandé la mise en place de mesures de filtrage pour le cabinet du ministre, et le ministre se retirera de toute discussion ou décision touchant M. Irving et ses entreprises.

floor: “We sell beer in all 50 states in the United States with pretty open borders and hopefully we'll get to that point in Canada soon.”

floor: They have already rigged the deck on the electoral reform committee, giving themselves a majority, when a majority of Canadians do not even support them.

Speaker: Hon. Maryam Monsef (Minister of Democratic Institutions, Lib.)
english: This may not be okay with the members opposite, but that is our way of ensuring that Canadians in 21st century Canada are included in this important conversation.
floor: This may not be okay with the members opposite, but that is our way of ensuring that Canadians in 21st century Canada are included in this important conversation.

floor: Madam Speaker, the government is committed to open and transparent competitions that balance the socio-economic needs of the government and the country with those of the industry that we have in this country.

floor: Madam Speaker, yesterday, the National Energy Board recommended the Kinder Morgan pipeline project for approval.

floor: We have asked that the panel members travel the pipeline route to hear from and talk to indigenous peoples and local communities, and report back to the minister by November 1, for a decision on or before December—

floor: Madam Speaker, the advisory panel of the Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard to study northern shrimp allocation is woefully unbalanced and biased.

floor: Why did the minister appoint someone with such a clear bias on shrimp allocation to his advisory panel?

floor: Will the government commit to introducing proactive pay equity legislation within the next six months, yes or no?

floor: Madam Speaker, having a gender wage gap in Canada in 2016 is unacceptable.

floor: De combien d'études le ministre de l'Agriculture et de l'Agroalimentaire a-t-il besoin seulement pour obliger l'étiquetage des saumons AquAdvantage?

english: Mr. Speaker, the uncertainty has been created by 10 years of a government that refused to understand that we can only build a strong economy when we are protecting the environment, when we are listening to Canadians, when we are building partnerships with indigenous peoples, and when we are respecting the science that surrounds all these projects.

floor: C'est pourquoi nous sommes fiers de mettre en avant un projet de loi sur Air Canada qui va garantir des emplois au Manitoba, en Ontario et au Québec dans les secteurs de la fabrication et de l'entretien des avions d'Air Canada.

floor: Nous allons bâtir une industrie aéronautique forte au Canada pour les années à venir, grâce à nos projets de loi et à notre engagement.

floor: La ministre peut-elle nous assurer qu'elle va tout mettre en oeuvre pour convaincre le premier ministre du Canada de l'importance de consulter tous les Canadiens et Canadiennes par voie de référendum?

floor: Yesterday's comments by the Attorney General on operational matters were beneath the dignity of his office.

Speaker: Ms. Christine Moore (Abitibi—Témiscamingue, NDP)
english: Since then, not only have the Conservatives not followed Health Canada's recommendations, which would result in health care savings of $9 billion, but even worse they decided to abandon the regulations, which were expected in 2010.
floor: Depuis, non seulement les conservateurs n'ont pas suivi les recommandations de Santé Canada, qui nous permettraient d'économiser 9 milliards de dollars en santé, mais pire encore, ils ont décidé d'abandonner la réglementation qui était pourtant prévue en 2010.

Speaker: Mr. Jean-François Fortin (Haute-Gaspésie—La Mitis—Matane—Matapédia, FD)

floor: La ministre des Transports va-t-elle s'assurer que le projet de développement du quai de Carleton-sur-Mer, un projet important et rassembleur pour la Gaspésie, sera rapidement traité?

Speaker: Mr. Colin Carrie (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment, CPC)
english: Since 2006, we have taken action on more than 2,700 substances under the chemicals management plan,
floor: Depuis 2006, nous avons pris des mesures pour lutter contre plus de 2 700 substances sur le plan de la gestion des produits chimiques.

Speaker: Mr. Colin Carrie (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment, CPC)
english: Since 2006, as I said in French, we have taken action on more than 2,700 substances under the chemicals management plan, and we are on track to assess 4,300 substances by 2020.
floor: Since 2006, as I said in French, we have taken action on more than 2,700 substances under the chemicals management plan, and we are on track to assess 4,300 substances by 2020.

Speaker: Mr. Jonathan Genest-Jourdain (Manicouagan, NDP)
english: In this case, the federal government clearly lacks political will, and the provinces are the ones showing the way. For example, Quebec recognized that residential schools were a form of cultural genocide against aboriginal nations.
floor: Dans ce cas-ci, le gouvernement fédéral manque clairement de volonté politique et ce sont les provinces qui montrent le chemin, comme le Québec, qui a reconnu que les pensionnats indiens étaient un outil de génocide culturel à l'égard des nations autochtones.

Speaker: Mr. Mark Strahl (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development, CPC)
english: It was our Prime Minister who set up the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which reported just last week.
floor: It was our Prime Minister who set up the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which reported just last week.

Speaker: Mrs. Cathy McLeod (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Health and for Western Economic Diversification, CPC)
english: Continued normalization through cookies and candies is, in our opinion, something that is going to be very detrimental to the health and safety of Canadians.
floor: Continued normalization through cookies and candies is, in our opinion, something that is going to be very detrimental to the health and safety of Canadians.

Speaker: Mr. Paul Calandra (Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and for Intergovernmental Affairs, CPC)
english: That is why I think like Canadians think.
floor: That is why I think like Canadians think.

Speaker: Mr. Peter Braid (Parliamentary Secretary for Infrastructure and Communities, CPC)
english: Of course, in our recent budget we announced the public transit fund.
floor: Of course, in our recent budget we announced the public transit fund.

Speaker: Mr. Andrew Saxton (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance, CPC)
english: Our government has delivered on its promise to Canadians to make life more affordable and continue to lower taxes.
floor: Our government has delivered on its promise to Canadians to make life more affordable and continue to lower taxes.

Speaker: Hon. Pierre Poilievre (Minister of Employment and Social Development and Minister for Democratic Reform, CPC)
english: In fact, Canada will play host to one of the issuances of the Magna Carta at the Canadian history museum.
floor: In fact, Canada will play host to one of the issuances of the Magna Carta at the Canadian history museum.

Speaker: Hon. Pierre Poilievre (Minister of Employment and Social Development and Minister for Democratic Reform, CPC)
english: It was one of the first examples of where the power of the Crown, also now known as the state, was restrained and the power of the individual was elevated.
floor: It was one of the first examples of where the power of the Crown, also now known as the state, was restrained and the power of the individual was elevated.

Speaker: Ms. Megan Leslie (Halifax, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, trying to cover up Senate scandals has become routine for the Prime Minister's Office: watering down an internal Senate report and a $90,000 cheque for Senator Duffy.
floor: Monsieur le Président, les tentatives de camoufler le scandale du Sénat sont devenues la norme au bureau du premier ministre: la dilution d'un rapport interne du Sénat et un chèque de 90 000 $ au sénateur Duffy. Or le rapport du vérificateur général sur le scandale du Sénat est encore plus désolant.

Speaker: Mr. Paul Calandra (Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and for Intergovernmental Affairs, CPC)
english: There is only one taxpayer and whether it is a senator or whether it is a member of Parliament, there are 68 members of the NDP caucus who owe $2.7 million.
floor: There is only one taxpayer and whether it is a senator or whether it is a member of Parliament, there are 68 members of the NDP caucus who owe $2.7 million.

Speaker: Mr. Paul Calandra (Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and for Intergovernmental Affairs, CPC)
english: I hope they will reflect on this and pay the money back.
floor: I hope they will reflect on this and pay the money back.

Speaker: Mr. Alexandre Boulerice (Rosemont—La Petite-Patrie, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, the people deserve the truth, and they deserve answers from their government.
floor: Monsieur le Président, les citoyens méritent la vérité, et ils méritent des réponses de la part de leur gouvernement.

Speaker: Hon. Pierre Poilievre (Minister of Employment and Social Development and Minister for Democratic Reform, CPC)
english: They are proposing a new $1,000 payroll tax on every single worker in Canada.
floor: They are proposing a new $1,000 payroll tax on every single worker in Canada.

english: Mr. Speaker, what the member is refusing to say is that, when the scandal broke, the Prime Minister came to Mike Duffy's defence.
floor: Monsieur le Président, ce qu'il refuse de dire, c'est que lorsque le scandale a éclaté, le premier ministre s'est précipité à la défense de Mike Duffy.

Speaker: Hon. Pierre Poilievre (Minister of Employment and Social Development and Minister for Democratic Reform, CPC)
english: That is a fair way to ensure that they have access to the benefits to which they are entitled.
floor: C'est une méthode juste afin de leur permettre d'avoir accès aux avantages auxquels ils ont droit.

Speaker: Ms. Niki Ashton (Churchill, NDP)
english: While we are there, it is pretty difficult to believe that the Conservatives are committed to reconciliation when the way they treat someone who is doing nothing more than fighting for fairness for aboriginal children is to respond by humiliating and ostracizing them.
floor: While we are there, it is pretty difficult to believe that the Conservatives are committed to reconciliation when the way they treat someone who is doing nothing more than fighting for fairness for aboriginal children is to respond by humiliating and ostracizing them.

Speaker: Mr. François Choquette (Drummond, NDP)
english: The NDP has shown leadership on the issue by successfully seeking unanimous consent of the House to have microbeads placed on Canada’s list of toxic substances.
floor: Le NPD a fait preuve de leadership sur la question en réussissant à avoir l'accord unanime de la Chambre pour ajouter les microbilles à la liste canadienne des substances toxiques.

Speaker: Hon. Leona Aglukkaq (Minister of the Environment, CPC)
english: We are also putting the issue of microbeads on the agenda of this summer's meetings of the Canadian Council of Ministers of the Environment.
floor: We are also putting the issue of microbeads on the agenda of this summer's meetings of the Canadian Council of Ministers of the Environment.

Speaker: Hon. K. Kellie Leitch (Minister of Labour and Minister of Status of Women, CPC)
english: What this government has been focused on is making sure that we take action, whether it be on matrimonial property rights, safety plans, or other initiatives to protect women.
floor: What this government has been focused on is making sure that we take action, whether it be on matrimonial property rights, safety plans, or other initiatives to protect women.

floor: In the spirit of reconciliation, will the Conservatives give the full subsidy to all northern fly-in communities that are currently not receiving it?

floor: We are committed to ensuring that northerners, like all Canadians, have access to nutritious food.

english: Will the government confront this new reality, bring in a new fiscal update before this session ends, and most important, come up with a real plan for jobs and growth?
floor: Will the government confront this new reality, bring in a new fiscal update before this session ends, and most important, come up with a real plan for jobs and growth?

floor: As this matter is currently before the courts, it would be inappropriate for me to comment further on this case.

floor: The New Democrats are irresponsible on these and other issues.

floor: Mr. Speaker, while both the NDP and Liberal Party have announced they support Kathleen Wynne's plan to bring in a $1,000 payroll tax on the average worker in Canada, we have done exactly the opposite.

Speaker: Ms. Roxanne James (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, again, we reject any claim that the RCMP did anything wrong by following the express will of Parliament, but it is interesting that the NDP continues to bring up this question, because the NDP, if ever given a chance, would bring that long gun registry back with everything else.
floor: Mr. Speaker, again, we reject any claim that the RCMP did anything wrong by following the express will of Parliament, but it is interesting that the NDP continues to bring up this question, because the NDP, if ever given a chance, would bring that long gun registry back with everything else.

Speaker: Mr. Alexandre Boulerice (Rosemont—La Petite-Patrie, NDP)
english: The Conservatives promised us a transparent, open and accountable government.
floor: Les conservateurs nous avaient promis un gouvernement de transparence, d'ouverture et d'intégrité.

Speaker: Ms. Lysane Blanchette-Lamothe (Pierrefonds—Dollard, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, the government suspended visa applications for people from Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, countries affected by the Ebola virus, in a move that was harshly criticized from the outset.
floor: Monsieur le Président, la suspension par le gouvernement de l'octroi de visas pour les personnes en provenance de la Guinée, du Liberia et de la Sierra Leone, pays touchés par le virus Ebola, a été vivement critiquée dès son entrée en vigueur.

Speaker: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development, CPC)
english: The government will continue to fulfill its obligations as set out in the agreement.
floor: The government will continue to fulfill its obligations as set out in the agreement.

floor: Monsieur le Président, je crois que le compte rendu va démontrer qu'on a fait des efforts significatifs pour améliorer la situation des membres des Premières Nations et des Autochtones, où qu'ils soient au Canada.

Speaker: Hon. John McCallum (Markham—Unionville, Lib.)
english: This government introduced voluntary savings plans, but Canadians still do not have enough money for their retirement.
floor: Ce gouvernement a mis en place des programmes volontaires d'épargne, mais les Canadiens n'ont toujours pas assez d'épargnes pour leur retraite.

Speaker: Hon. Steven Blaney (Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: While training and procurement are matters that fall under the direct purview of the RCMP, our government supports Canada's law enforcement agencies with legislative tools, resources like we find in budget 2015, that the member could support, which they need to get the job done, fighting crime and ensuring the safety and security of our communities.
floor: While training and procurement are matters that fall under the direct purview of the RCMP, our government supports Canada's law enforcement agencies with legislative tools, resources like we find in budget 2015, that the member could support, which they need to get the job done, fighting crime and ensuring the safety and security of our communities.

floor: We are on the eve of a new Auditor General report that could put 14 senators in jail.

floor: Mr. Speaker, this is a further indication of global economic uncertainty—

floor: Mr. Speaker, the export contract that the member refers to is the largest in Canadian history and will create and sustain more than 3,000 direct jobs in southwestern Ontario alone.

english: Immediate action is needed, but the Conservatives are stalling and refusing to commit to a timeline for the arrival of new RCMP officers in Surrey.
floor: Immediate action is needed, but the Conservatives are stalling and refusing to commit to a timeline for the arrival of new RCMP officers in Surrey.

floor: I am proud to stand up with members who are supportive of preventing gang violence in Surrey with programs that have proven efficient and who work with the Government of British Columbia and the school board.

floor: Nous avons réussi à réduire les arriérés partout, mais il y a des cas plus compliqués, et il faut en parler en personne et non pas en public à la Chambre.

Speaker: Hon. Thomas Mulcair (Leader of the Opposition, NDP)
english: Five separate drafts were concocted.
floor: Five separate drafts were concocted.

english: When will the Prime Minister order the full Duffy audit released?
floor: When will the Prime Minister order the full Duffy audit released?

english: What we will not do is reach into the pockets of Canadians with a mandatory payroll tax and take money out of their pockets.
floor: What we will not do is reach into the pockets of Canadians with a mandatory payroll tax and take money out of their pockets.

floor: Monsieur le Président, c'est pitoyable d'écouter une néo-démocrate qui prétend que le bilan libéral en matière d'immigration était un modèle.

Speaker: Mr. Dennis Bevington (Northwest Territories, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, the Auditor General has shown that the nutrition north criteria are not fair or accessible.
floor: Mr. Speaker, the Auditor General has shown that the nutrition north criteria are not fair or accessible.

english: Mr. Speaker, I cannot help but add that if they were able to impose this carbon tax, it would be even colder.
floor: Mr. Speaker, I cannot help but add that if they were able to impose this carbon tax, it would be even colder.

floor: Monsieur le Président, j'aimerais simplement rappeler que Postes Canada a fait presque 200 millions de dollars de profit juste l'an passé.

Speaker: Hon. Leona Aglukkaq (Minister of the Environment, Minister of the Canadian Northern Economic Development Agency and Minister for the Arctic Council, CPC)
english: That translates to 225 megatonnes.
floor: That translates to 225 megatonnes.

floor: Transport Canada, in the situation of the airbags, has received no complaints related to this issue from Canadians and is not aware of any incidents having taken place in Canada.

floor: Mr. Speaker, if the government did not get the hint already, today Ottawa city council formally voted to ask the Conservatives to move the memorial for victims of Communism back to its original site.

floor: Nous partageons l'immense chagrin des familles touchées par cet événement tragique.

floor: Nous allons continuer de réduire les impôts et les taxes pour atteindre le succès, comme les 1,2 million de nouveaux emplois créés.

floor: When the employment minister uses taxpayer money for self-promotion videos to get re-elected and then has the gall to say that he is merely informing Canadians about government policy, it is like a slap in the face to all Canadians who expect accountability.

floor: These changes do not impose a legislated regime.

floor: Does the current government just not get that Canadians want to share in the economy of the future, created through investments in a clean, renewable energy economy?

floor: Mr. Speaker, no one disagrees with the idea of the memorial, but what is with the high-handed attitude of the government?

floor: Mr. Speaker, let me be very clear.

floor: Our government wants to help all Canadian families succeed by keeping taxes low and delivering programs like the universal child care benefit and family tax cut.

floor: Monsieur le Président, depuis 40 ans, l'organisme Femmes Autochtones du Québec se porte à la défense des femmes autochtones violentées.

english: Can the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister update this House on what infrastructure initiative our government is launching to mark this occasion?
floor: Can the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister update this House on what infrastructure initiative our government is launching to mark this occasion?

floor: While Liberals and Conservatives are feeding at the trough in the Senate, the current Conservative government is sitting idly by watching good middle-class jobs disappear.

floor: We signed a free trade agreement with the European Union that will deliver 80,000 net new jobs, including in Honda Canada, which announced recently in the presence of the Prime Minister that it will export vehicles directly to Europe from Canada, creating 400 net new jobs in that one plant alone.

Speaker: Ms. Roxanne James (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: However, as I stated last week, I would like point out that on this side of the House we actually support our law enforcement in Canada.
floor: However, as I stated last week, I would like point out that on this side of the House we actually support our law enforcement in Canada.

english: Mr. Speaker, I can confirm that steps are being taken to bring this agreement into force.
floor: Mr. Speaker, I can confirm that steps are being taken to bring this agreement into force.

floor: They have absolutely no credibility on trade.

floor: Monsieur le Président, l'inquiétude règne dans la communauté haïtienne depuis que le gouvernement conservateur a levé le moratoire sur les déportations vers Haïti et le Zimbabwe de plus de 3 500 personnes.

floor: Mr. Speaker, I did speak a moment ago of Circles of Support, but I also want to point out that the Commissioner of the Correctional Service of Canada actually said that 95% of inmates who were released had completed their recognized programs in relation to the correctional program.

floor: Monsieur le Président, c'était dans le budget, mais Québec attend encore de voir si les Grands voiliers 2017 vont finalement recevoir l'argent promis pour leur réalisation.

floor: The Liberals are really scrambling today after it having been revealed that there are billions of dollars in uncosted spending in their plan.

floor: Mr. Speaker, Canadians plan for their retirement based on what they are promised through their pension plans.

floor: I would encourage him to do the right thing for taxpayers and pay the money back.

floor: That is why the Chief of the Defence Staff ordered an external independent review into how the Canadian Armed Forces deals with sexual misconduct and sexual harassment.

floor: As to the Auditor General's report, National Defence accepts all the recommendations from the Auditor General's investigation.

floor: Will the current government advertise its $12-million cut for species at risk?

floor: Now Stephen Toope, former dean of law at McGill, former UBC president, and currently the director of the Munk School of Global Affairs, has called Bill C-51:...so badly drafted, so expansive in scope, and so open to abuse that one must wonder how a responsible political leadership could bring it forward.

floor: Will the Conservatives stop making excuses and make funds available to protect the people in my community?

floor: The Liberals and the NDP want high taxes on middle-class families, high taxes on middle-class seniors, and high taxes on middle-class consumers.

floor: Mr. Speaker, the finance minister made it clear to Canadians that Conservatives only care about short-term political gain when he said that the TFSA increase for the rich will be paid for Canada's next generation, and “why don't we leave that to [the Prime Minister's] granddaughter to solve”.

Speaker: Hon. K. Kellie Leitch (Minister of Labour and Minister of Status of Women, CPC)
english: The NDP totally opposed all those things.
floor: The NDP totally opposed all those things.

Speaker: Mr. Frank Valeriote (Guelph, Lib.)
english: Why are the Conservatives so stubbornly refusing to present a plan that will honour our sacred obligation to veterans and all their families?
floor: Why are the Conservatives so stubbornly refusing to present a plan that will honour our sacred obligation to veterans and all their families?

Speaker: Ms. Irene Mathyssen (London—Fanshawe, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, Ontario farmers are worried because avian flu has been confirmed on a second farm in Oxford County, and the quarantine now stretches into the Waterloo Region.
floor: Mr. Speaker, Ontario farmers are worried because avian flu has been confirmed on a second farm in Oxford County, and the quarantine now stretches into the Waterloo Region.

Speaker: Ms. Irene Mathyssen (London—Fanshawe, NDP)
english: Will the Conservatives reverse their destructive cuts to CFIA?
floor: Will the Conservatives reverse their destructive cuts to CFIA?

Speaker: Hon. Wayne Easter (Malpeque, Lib.)
english: Surely, when the Prime Minister uses a makeup artist, any makeup artist who is given the kind of close access to the Prime Minister would have to go through an RCMP background check.
floor: Surely, when the Prime Minister uses a makeup artist, any makeup artist who is given the kind of close access to the Prime Ministerwould have to go through an RCMP background check.

Speaker: Mr. Nathan Cullen (Skeena—Bulkley Valley, NDP)
english: It has become so absurd that the Alaska State legislature recently voted unanimously to offer to pay Canada to keep its border open.
floor: It has become so absurd that the Alaska State legislature recently voted unanimously to offer to pay Canada to keep its border open.

Speaker: Ms. Roxanne James (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, our government is focused on ensuring that our shared border is secure, while easing the flow of legitimate travel and trade.
floor: Mr. Speaker, our government is focused on ensuring that our shared border is secure, while easing the flow of legitimate travel and trade.

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: It is not Saskatchewan, Quebec, or everywhere else where he tried to use parliamentary funds to establish party offices.
floor: It is not Saskatchewan, Quebec, or everywhere else where he tried to use parliamentary funds to establish party offices.

Speaker: Mr. Charlie Angus (Timmins—James Bay, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, former Senate law clerk Mark Audcent has testified that it was the business of the Prime Minister's Office to vet Senate appointees to see if they were actually eligible to sit in the Senate.
floor: Mr. Speaker, former Senate law clerk Mark Audcent has testified that it was the business of the Prime Minister's Office to vet Senate appointees to see if they were actually eligible to sit in the Senate.

Speaker: Mr. Francis Scarpaleggia (Lac-Saint-Louis, Lib.)
english: Why, in budget after budget, has the Conservative government done nothing to ensure food safety for Canadians? Why has it gotten to the point that we have an inspection crisis that will be difficult to resolve?
floor: Pourquoi, budget après budget, ce gouvernement conservateur n'a-t-il pas veillé à la sécurité alimentaire des Canadiens, au point où nous vivons maintenant une crise de l'inspection que nous ne pourrons pas facilement régler?

Speaker: Mr. Andrew Saxton (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance, CPC)
english: The Liberal leader's same old high-tax, high-debt agenda is perhaps underpinned by his position that a budget can simply balance itself.
floor: The Liberal leader's same old high-tax, high-debt agenda is perhaps underpinned by his position that a budget can simply balance itself.

Speaker: Hon. Shelly Glover (Minister of Canadian Heritage and Official Languages, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, let me be clear: the Canadian Science and Engineering Hall of Fame is simply housed at the museum.
floor: Monsieur le Président, je veux être claire: le Panthéon canadien des sciences et du génie s'est tout simplement logé au musée.

Speaker: Mr. Adam Vaughan (Trinity—Spadina, Lib.)
english: Mr. Speaker, during the debate yesterday we learned that in the middle of a disastrous oil spill in Vancouver, nobody in the federal government thought it was necessary to contact Vancouver city hall.
floor: Mr. Speaker, during the debate yesterday we learned that in the middle of a disastrous oil spill in Vancouver, nobody in the federal government thought it was necessary to contact Vancouver city hall.

Speaker: Hon. Ed Holder (Minister of State (Science and Technology), CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, the pyrrhotite problem falls under provincial jurisdiction.
floor: Monsieur le Président, le problème de la pyrrhotite en est un de compétence provinciale.

Speaker: Mr. Ryan Leef (Yukon, CPC)
english: Could the Minister of the Environment update the House on what our government is doing and how we are investing in the great people of Canada's north?
floor: Could the Minister of the Environment update the House on what our government is doing and how we are investing in the great people of Canada's north?

Speaker: Mr. Louis Plamondon (Bas-Richelieu—Nicolet—Bécancour, BQ)
english: Mr. Speaker, after investing in Churchill Falls, which will be in direct competition with Hydro-Quebec and Quebec's revenues, after imposing a toll on the new Champlain Bridge and after condoning the comments of a member who said he was fed up with the National Assembly's unanimous declarations, now the federal government is once again taking unilateral action with its reform of the temporary foreign worker program, despite repeated requests from Quebec's labour minister.
floor: Monsieur le Président, après avoir investi dans Churchill Falls, qui va entrer en compétition directe avec Hydro-Québec et les revenus du Québec, après avoir imposé un péage sur le nouveau pont Champlain, et après avoir toléré les propos d'un député qui affirmait qu'il en avait soupé des déclarations unanimes de l'Assemblée nationale, voilà que le gouvernement fédéral agit encore à sens unique avec sa réforme du Programme des travailleurs étrangers temporaires, malgré les demandes répétées de la ministre du Travail du Québec.

Speaker: Mrs. Maria Mourani (Ahuntsic, Ind.)
english: Mr. Speaker, in December 2014, the government ended the moratorium on deporting some 3,000 citizens of Haiti and Zimbabwe, requiring them to obtain status by June 1, 2015.
floor: Monsieur le Président, en décembre 2014, le gouvernement levait le moratoire sur le renvoi d'environ 3 000 ressortissants d'Haïti et du Zimbabwe, exigeant la régularisation de leur statut d'ici le 1er juin 2015.

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: We have done a lot for the manufacturing sector despite opposition from the NDP.
floor: Nous avons fait beaucoup pour ce secteur malgré l'opposition du NPD.

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: The NDP voted against the automotive innovation fund for the auto industry and against the national shipbuilding procurement strategy—
floor: Le NPD a voté contre le Fonds d'innovation pour le secteur de l'automobile et contre la Stratégie nationale d'approvisionnement en matière de construction...

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: We are still trying to find 40 million of those dollars.
floor: We are still trying to find 40 million of those dollars.

Speaker: Ms. Ève Péclet (La Pointe-de-l'Île, NDP)
english: The Information Commissioner was clear: “Although the Act was intended to shine a light on government decisions, it has become a shield against transparency and has encouraged a culture of delay.”
floor: Ce que dit la commissaire à l'information est sans équivoque: « la Loi, qui devait faire la lumière sur les décisions du gouvernement, est devenue un bouclier contre la transparence et a encouragé une culture du retard ».

Speaker: Hon. Dominic LeBlanc (Beauséjour, Lib.)
english: Instead of doing something about it, the Conservatives keep singing the praises of the Minister of Finance, who keeps failing to show up for work.
floor: Au lieu d'agir, les conservateurs célèbrent la disparition du ministre des Finances.

Speaker: Hon. Ralph Goodale (Wascana, Lib.)
english: Mr. Speaker, here is the government's record: the economy is shrinking, unemployment is up, TD Bank says it is getting worse, CIBC says job quality is at the lowest ebb in 25 years, BNN is reporting the most pessimistic business outlook since the last recession, and the Bank of Canada says only substantial monetary stimulus is keeping Canada from falling back into recession.
floor: Mr. Speaker, here is the government's record: the economy is shrinking, unemployment is up, TD Bank says it is getting worse, CIBC says job quality is at the lowest ebb in 25 years, BNN is reporting the most pessimistic business outlook since the last recession, and the Bank of Canada says only substantial monetary stimulus is keeping Canada from falling back into recession.

Speaker: Ms. Niki Ashton (Churchill, NDP)
english: These are very strong words, words that must be acknowledged by the Prime Minister.
floor: These are very strong words, words that must be acknowledged by the Prime Minister.

Speaker: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, it is strange to see this member make this kind of accusation when at every step of the measures we have taken and are taking to improve and reduce the gaps between aboriginal and non-aboriginal Canadians, this party, the NDP, votes against each and every measure.
floor: Mr. Speaker, it is strange to see this member make this kind of accusation when at every step of the measures we have taken and are taking to improve and reduce the gaps between aboriginal and non-aboriginal Canadians, this party, the NDP, votes against each and every measure.

Speaker: M. François Pilon (Laval—Les Îles, NPD)
english: Residents are outraged by the lack of public consultation, and the mayor of Laval deplores the one-way communications from Canada Post.
floor: Les citoyens sont outrés par le manque de consultation de la population, et le maire de Laval déplore les communications à sens unique avec Postes Canada.

Speaker: M. François Pilon (Laval—Les Îles, NPD)
english: Will the government honour the City of Laval's request or will it plough ahead with the installation of community boxes?
floor: Le gouvernement va-t-il respecter la demande de la Ville de Laval ou bien va-t-il continuer à forcer l'installation de boîtes postales communautaires?

Speaker: Mr. Marc Garneau (Westmount—Ville-Marie, Lib.)
english: Outside of a full recession, we have had the slowest consecutive 15 months of job growth on record.
floor: Outside of a full recession, we have had the slowest consecutive 15 months of job growth on record.

Speaker: Ms. Roxanne James (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: I would like to remind the member opposite that we have a strong system of gun control in Canada, and our government has toughened laws and penalties for those who commit crimes with guns.
floor: I would like to remind the member opposite that we have a strong system of gun control in Canada, and our government has toughened laws and penalties for those who commit crimes with guns.

Speaker: Hon. Pierre Poilievre (Minister of Employment and Social Development and Minister for Democratic Reform, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, the reason the Liberals want a budget is so that they can increase taxes for Canadian families. Canadians do not want the Liberal Party's tax increases.
floor: Monsieur le Président, la raison pour laquelle les libéraux veulent un budget, c'est qu'ils veulent augmenter les impôts et les taxes pour les familles canadiennes.

Speaker: Mr. Adam Vaughan (Trinity—Spadina, Lib.)
english: They also do not get something else from the current government: infrastructure money.
floor: They also do not get something else from the current government: infrastructure money.

Speaker: Mr. Murray Rankin (Victoria, NDP)
english: Conservative cuts are simply destroying our public broadcaster.
floor: Conservative cuts are simply destroying our public broadcaster.

Speaker: Ms. Linda Duncan (Edmonton—Strathcona, NDP)
english: Will the minister, who has made this shameful, groundless insult to Alberta first nations, stand and apologize?
floor: Will the minister, who has made this shameful, groundless insult to Alberta first nations, stand and apologize?

Speaker: Hon. Wayne Easter (Malpeque, Lib.)
english: That is unacceptable and it is doing it in order to give a tax break to the rich.
floor: That is unacceptable and it is doing it in order to give a tax break to the rich.

Speaker: Ms. Charmaine Borg (Terrebonne—Blainville, NDP)
english: Canada Post is ignoring the diversity of municipalities.
floor: Postes Canada ne prend aucunement en considération la diversité des réalités municipales.

Speaker: Hon. Pierre Poilievre (Minister of Employment and Social Development and Minister for Democratic Reform, CPC)
english: We are giving the dollars back to the more than eight million real child care experts who are out there, and their names are Mom and Dad.
floor: We are giving the dollars back to the more than eight million real child care experts who are out there, and their names are Mom and Dad.

Speaker: Mme Manon Perreault (Montcalm, Ind.)
english: That being said, is there now a labour policy adapted to the needs of this client group?
floor: Cela dit, est-ce qu'il y a maintenant une politique de travail adaptée aux besoins de cette clientèle?

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: This group, the so-called Islamic State, represents a direct threat not just to the region.
floor: This group, the so-called Islamic State, represents a direct threat not just to the region.

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: I hear no compelling argument on the other side as to why we should completely ignore the very real threat to this country, which Canadians know exists.
floor: I hear no compelling argument on the other side as to why we should completely ignore the very real threat to this country, which Canadians know exists.

Speaker: Hon. Steven Blaney (Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: I hope the opposition will listen to the voice of the sister of fallen Warrant Officer Patrice Vincent.
floor: I hope the opposition will listen to the voice of the sister of fallen Warrant Officer Patrice Vincent.

Speaker: L'hon. Steven Blaney (ministre de la Sécurité publique et de la Protection civile, PCC)
english: There are several provisions in Bill C-51 regarding review processes and judicial oversight.
floor: Il y a plusieurs dispositions dans le projet de loi C-51, notamment en ce qui concerne les processus de révision et de supervision judiciaire.

Speaker: Hon. Kerry-Lynne D. Findlay (Minister of National Revenue, CPC)
english: The CRA has taken concrete measures to strengthen privacy management, as recommended by the PC, by implementing a CRA directorate responsible for CRA policy and assessment procedures, a proactive training program to ensure CRA employees are fully informed of their duties to protect the privacy of Canadians and by revising security and privacy related processes.
floor: The CRA has taken concrete measures to strengthen privacy management, as recommended by the PC, by implementing a CRA directorate responsible for CRA policy and assessment procedures, a proactive training program to ensure CRA employees are fully informed of their duties to protect the privacy of Canadians and by revising security and privacy related processes.

Speaker: Hon. Pierre Poilievre (Minister of Employment and Social Development and Minister for Democratic Reform, CPC)
english: We on this side of the House are working to reduce taxes, boost training for in-demand jobs and sign free trade agreements that create demand for our Canadian products.
floor: De ce côté-ci de la Chambre, nous travaillons afin de réduire les taxes, d'augmenter la formation pour des métiers en demande et de signer des ententes de libre-échange qui créent la demande de nos produits canadiens.

Speaker: Hon. Chris Alexander (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, CPC)
english: Last year, the number of new Canadian citizens even exceeded the number of new immigrants.
floor: L'année passée, le nombre de nouveaux citoyens au Canada a même dépassé le nombre de nouveaux immigrants.

Speaker: Mr. Andrew Cash (Davenport, NDP)
english: The fact is that Conservatives have repeatedly and systematically made it more difficult for immigrants to become citizens.
floor: The fact is that Conservatives have repeatedly and systematically made it more difficult for immigrants to become citizens.

Speaker: Ms. Joyce Murray (Vancouver Quadra, Lib.)
english: In the meantime she has no income, she is about to lose her housing, and she is still not receiving the benefits she is entitled to.
floor: In the meantime she has no income, she is about to lose her housing, and she is still not receiving the benefits she is entitled to.

Speaker: Mr. Scott Andrews (Avalon, Ind.)
english: Mr. Speaker, a woman from Newfoundland and Labrador recently had her sealskin purse confiscated by U.S. Customs and Border Protection because seals are on the endangered species list in the United States.
floor: Mr. Speaker, a woman from Newfoundland and Labrador recently had her sealskin purse confiscated by U.S. Customs and Border Protection because seals are on the endangered species list in the United States.

Speaker: Ms. Megan Leslie (Halifax, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, the foreign minister of Turkey stated that someone working for an intelligence agency within the coalition against ISIS may have attempted to assist three British schoolgirls in joining that terrorist organization.
floor: Monsieur le Président, le ministre des Affaires étrangères de la Turquie a déclaré qu'un individu travaillant pour une agence de renseignement de la coalition contre le groupe État islamique aurait aidé trois jeunes Britanniques à se joindre à l'organisation terroriste.

Speaker: Mr. Randall Garrison (Esquimalt—Juan de Fuca, NDP)
english: Why are the Conservatives refusing to allow the Privacy Commissioner to appear before the committee so all Canadians can hear his concerns?
floor: Why are the Conservatives refusing to allow the Privacy Commissioner to appear before the committee so all Canadians can hear his concerns?

english: Such things can be overlooked, which is what happened in Markham after the Prime Minister's former chief of staff got involved.
floor: On passe par-dessus, comme cela s'est passé à Markham, après que l'ancien chef de cabinet du premier ministre s'en soit mêlé.

Speaker: Hon. Diane Finley (Minister of Public Works and Government Services, CPC)
english: It is unfortunate that the NDP voted against this program that has benefited virtually all of their constituents.
floor: It is unfortunate that the NDP voted against this program that has benefited virtually all of their constituents.

Speaker: Hon. Jason Kenney (Minister of National Defence and Minister for Multiculturalism, CPC)
english: The member, and all members, have my assurance that I will review the report closely and work with the Provost Marshal of the Canadian Armed Forces to make whatever changes are necessary to ensure that the totally unacceptable conduct that occurred in this matter does not repeat itself.
floor: The member, and all members, have my assurance that I will review the report closely and work with the Provost Marshal of the Canadian Armed Forces to make whatever changes are necessary to ensure that the totally unacceptable conduct that occurred in this matter does not repeat itself.

Speaker: L'hon. Steven Blaney (ministre de la Sécurité publique et de la Protection civile, PCC)
english: I thank our police forces—
floor: Je remercie nos services policiers...

Speaker: Mr. Murray Rankin (Victoria, NDP)
english: When will the government give up its unjustifiable attack on Canadian charities?
floor: When will the government give up its unjustifiable attack on Canadian charities?

Speaker: Hon. Kerry-Lynne D. Findlay (Minister of National Revenue, CPC)

floor: Why is the NDP attempting to score cheap political points at the expense of professional public servants at the CRA?

floor: Yet, Alberta's finance minister is set to deliver a budget on March 26.

Speaker: Ms. Manon Perreault (Montcalm, Ind.)
english: With Bill C-51, the government is overlooking key safety issues and sidestepping other serious problems.
floor: Avec le projet de loi C-51, le gouvernement évite les principaux enjeux de sécurité et contourne d'autres problèmes très sérieux.

Speaker: Mr. Marc Garneau (Westmount—Ville-Marie, Lib.)
english: According to the CIBC's analysis, job quality in Canada is the lowest it has been in the 15 years that the bank has been collecting statistics.
floor: Selon l'analyse effectuée par la CIBC, la qualité des emplois au Canada a atteint son niveau le plus bas depuis les 15 années qu'elle recueille des statistiques.

Speaker: Mr. Marc Garneau (Westmount—Ville-Marie, Lib.)
english: What is the government doing to respond to the deterioration of job quality?
floor: Que fait le gouvernement pour répondre à la détérioration de la qualité des emplois?

Speaker: Mr. Charlie Angus (Timmins—James Bay, NDP)

floor: Let us stick on the issue here, because not only are Conservative insiders being subpoenaed, but last week we learned that a number of key Conservative MPs have been called to testify.

Speaker: Hon. Pierre Poilievre (Minister of Employment and Social Development and Minister for Democratic Reform, CPC)
english: We have limited the percentage of foreign workers in a given workplace.
floor: Nous avons d'ailleurs limité le pourcentage de travailleurs étrangers dans un lieu de travail donné.

Speaker: Ms. Irene Mathyssen (London—Fanshawe, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, while eating breakfast before heading to work, a Timmins father found a note from workers who are now out of work.
floor: Mr. Speaker, while eating breakfast before heading to work, a Timmins father found a note from workers who are now out of work.

Speaker: Ms. Roxanne James (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: When we talk about activities that would warrant information sharing, I am just going to list a few: espionage, sabotage, covert foreign influence activities and terrorism.
floor: When we talk about activities that would warrant information sharing, I am just going to list a few: espionage, sabotage, covert foreign influence activities and terrorism.

Speaker: Hon. Jason Kenney (Minister of National Defence and Minister for Multiculturalism, CPC)
english: These dangerous narcotics would have otherwise landed on our streets and in our communities.
floor: These dangerous narcotics would have otherwise landed on our streets and in our communities.

Speaker: Hon. Shelly Glover (Minister of Canadian Heritage and Official Languages, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, I find the question somewhat surprising from that member, who used to be a Liberal minister during the nineties when they cut almost $400 million from CBC.
floor: Mr. Speaker, I find the question somewhat surprising from that member, who used to be a Liberal minister during the nineties when they cut almost $400 million from CBC.

Speaker: Mr. François Lapointe (Montmagny—L'Islet—Kamouraska—Rivière-du-Loup, NDP)
english: Will he at least commit to using all the money voted by Parliament for that purpose this year?
floor: Va-t-il au moins s'engager cette année à utiliser toutes les sommes votées par le Parlement à cet effet?

Speaker: Hon. Rob Nicholson (Minister of Foreign Affairs, CPC)
english: Canada encourages the governments of the Dominican Republic and Haiti to work together in good faith to resolve these issues as quickly as possible in a non-violent manner.
floor: Canada encourages the governments of the Dominican Republic and Haiti to work together in good faith to resolve these issues as quickly as possible in a non-violent manner.

Speaker: Mr. Robert Goguen (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice, CPC)
english: Canadians have diverse viewpoints on this, and our plan is to engage all Canadians in a consultation process that will take into consideration the diverse viewpoints of all Canadians in order to reach a conclusion that is acceptable to everyone.
floor: Les points de vue sont très divers chez les Canadiens, et notre plan est d'engager tous les Canadiens dans une consultation qui prendra en considération les divers points de vue de tous les Canadiens pour en arriver à des concessions acceptables pour tous.

Speaker: Mr. Justin Trudeau (Papineau, Lib.)
english: With President Obama's veto of the Keystone XL pipeline, the Prime Minister has not fulfilled that responsibility.
floor: With President Obama's veto of the Keystone XL pipeline, the Prime Minister has not fulfilled that responsibility.

Speaker: Mr. Randall Garrison (Esquimalt—Juan de Fuca, NDP)
english: Open-ended surveillance and maintenance of these records is concerning for Canadians, especially given the weak oversight of security agencies like the Communications Security Establishment.
floor: Open-ended surveillance and maintenance of these records is concerning for Canadians, especially given the weak oversight of security agencies like the Communications Security Establishment.

Speaker: Hon. Steven Blaney (Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: It is important to remember the measures that we have introduced, such as the legislation to combat terrorism, revoke passports and revoke the dual citizenship of individuals found guilty of terrorism, as well as Bill C-51, which is before us now.
floor: Il est important de rappeler les mesures que nous avons mis en avant, comme la loi pour combattre le terrorisme, la révocation des passeports, la révocation de la double citoyenneté pour les personnes reconnues coupables de terrorisme, ainsi que le projet de loi C-51devant nous.

Speaker: Mr. Nathan Cullen (Skeena—Bulkley Valley, NDP)
english: How can Conservative priorities be so out of whack and offline with what Canadians actually need and deserve?
floor: How can Conservative priorities be so out of whack and offline with what Canadians actually need and deserve?

Speaker: Hon. Tony Clement (President of the Treasury Board, CPC)
english: Every year, we table a budget which is good news for Canadians and every year the opposition votes against it.
floor: Every year, we table a budget which is good news for Canadians and every year the opposition votes against it.

Speaker: Hon. K. Kellie Leitch (Minister of Labour and Minister of Status of Women, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, as I said yesterday in the House, the Government of Canada will have a representative at the round table.
floor: Mr. Speaker, as I said yesterday in the House, the Government of Canada will have a representative at the round table.

Speaker: Hon. K. Kellie Leitch (Minister of Labour and Minister of Status of Women, CPC)
english: That is what families are looking for.
floor: That is what families are looking for.

Speaker: Hon. Kerry-Lynne D. Findlay (Minister of National Revenue, CPC)
english: The CRA has an excellent record of combatting international tax evasion through over 8,600 cases identifying over $5.6 billion in additional taxes.
floor: The CRA has an excellent record of combatting international tax evasion through over 8,600 cases identifying over $5.6 billion in additional taxes.

english: Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question, because it allows me to talk about the Canada Transportation Act review, which this government has embarked on early in order to deal with issues outstanding with respect to the transportation of grain in the country.
floor: Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question, because it allows me to talk about the Canada Transportation Act review, which this government has embarked on early in order to deal with issues outstanding with respect to the transportation of grain in the country.

Speaker: Ms. Roxanne James (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: That member's remark was absolutely false.
floor: That member's remark was absolutely false.

Speaker: Mme Sadia Groguhé (Saint-Lambert, NPD)
english: Mr. Speaker, child pornography investigations are not the only thing suffering as a result of the Conservatives' surreptitious cuts.
floor: Monsieur le Président, il n'y a pas que les enquêtes sur la pornographie juvénile qui font les frais des compressions sournoises des conservateurs.

Speaker: Mr. Andrew Saxton (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance, CPC)
english: While we are focused on creating jobs, the Liberal leader has the old Liberal high-tax, high-debt agenda that would threaten jobs and set working families back.
floor: While we are focused on creating jobs, the Liberal leader has the old Liberal high-tax, high-debt agenda that would threaten jobs and set working families back.

Speaker: Ms. Roxanne James (Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, CPC)
english: This is a normal practice, and I wish the opposition would stop playing political games with such an important issue.
floor: This is a normal practice, and I wish the opposition would stop playing political games with such an important issue.

english: The Liberal member knows full well—
floor: The Liberal member knows full well—

floor: These communities experience major response time delays that can have devastating and tragic impacts.

floor: Will the minister recognize this crisis and work with these communities so they get the protection they need and deserve, or will the government continue to turn a blind eye and continue to put people at risk?

floor: Mr. Speaker, Canada's natural resource sector supports an impressive 1.8 million good paying jobs.

english: Could the minister share with the House what we are doing to provide benefits for working Canadians?
floor: Could the minister share with the House what we are doing to provide benefits for working Canadians?

Speaker: Mr. Claude Patry (Jonquière—Alma, BQ)
english: Mr. Speaker, while the current Quebec government is hurting the regions by making ill-advised decisions to supposedly improve public finances, the fiscal imbalance between Ottawa and the provinces continues to grow.
floor: Monsieur le Président, alors que l'actuel gouvernement du Québec frappe les régions en prenant des décisions mal avisées pour soi-disant assainir les finances publiques, le déséquilibre fiscal entre Ottawa et les provinces ne cesse de s'accroître.

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, we believe that a large percentage of Quebeckers agree with our government on tax breaks, tax cuts, direct benefits to families and the fight against crime and terrorism, rather than with a party that wants to increase taxes, provides benefits to bureaucrats and unions, and does not take the fight against terrorists, jihadists and criminals seriously.
floor: Monsieur le Président, nous croyons qu'une grande proportion de Québécois et de Québécoises sont d'accord avec notre gouvernement concernant l'allégement du fardeau fiscal, la baisse des taxes et des impôts, les avantages directs aux familles et la lutte contre la criminalité et le terrorisme, plutôt qu'avec un parti qui veut hausser les taxes et les impôts, qui apporte des avantages à des bureaucraties et des syndicats et qui ne prend pas au sérieux la lutte contre les terroristes, les djihadistes et les criminels.

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: These vaccines have historically proven extremely effective in reducing and in some cases even eliminating certain types of previously debilitating ailments.
floor: These vaccines have historically proven extremely effective in reducing and in some cases even eliminating certain types of previously debilitating ailments.

Speaker: Mr. Justin Trudeau (Papineau, Lib.)
english: Furthermore, Mr. Harper cut the budget by 23%—
floor: De plus, M. Harper a réduit de 23 % le budget...

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: Vaccines have historically proven effective in improving the health of our children and families.
floor: Le bilan historique est très clair en ce qui concerne l'utilité de ces vaccins pour améliorer la santé de nos enfants et de nos familles.

Speaker: Hon. Judy Sgro (York West, Lib.)
english: Does the minister agree that the only thing growing faster than GTA potholes is the Conservative addiction to lavish partisan ads?
floor: Does the minister agree that the only thing growing faster than GTA potholes is the Conservative addiction to lavish partisan ads?

Speaker: Hon. Ed Fast (Minister of International Trade, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, as I already mentioned, this government took the step of taking this dispute to the World Trade Organization, where we believe we will prevail.
floor: Mr. Speaker, as I already mentioned, this government took the step of taking this dispute to the World Trade Organization, where we believe we will prevail.

Speaker: Mr. Pierre Nantel (Longueuil—Pierre-Boucher, NDP)
english: Now that their contempt is on public display, will the minister finally confess that she and her government take malicious pleasure in sucking the life out of the CBC?
floor: Maintenant que leur mépris est sur la place publique, est-ce que la ministre peut enfin avouer qu'elle et son gouvernement prennent un malin plaisir à saigner CBC/Radio-Canada?

Speaker: Mr. Murray Rankin (Victoria, NDP)
english: Recently, the spokesperson for the Thalidomide Victims Association said, “Members are starting to fear it was all a facade”.
floor: Recently, the spokesperson for the Thalidomide Victims Association said, “Members are starting to fear it was all a façade”.

Speaker: Mr. Daryl Kramp (Prince Edward—Hastings, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, before Bill C-31, CRA officials were inexplicably prohibited from passing along evidence of serious criminal activity, uncovered on the job, to relevant law enforcement agencies.
floor: Mr. Speaker, before Bill C-31, CRA officials were inexplicably prohibited from passing along evidence of serious criminal activity, uncovered on the job, to relevant law enforcement agencies.

Speaker: Hon. Candice Bergen (Minister of State (Social Development), CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the member for Don Valley East for the good work he is doing to support families in his riding.
floor: Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the member for Don Valley Eastfor the good work he is doing to support families in his riding.

Speaker: Hon. James Moore (Minister of Industry, CPC)
english: For example, we are putting forward our national shipbuilding procurement policy, which the NDP has opposed.
floor: For example, we are putting forward our national shipbuilding procurement policy, which the NDP has opposed.

Speaker: Ms. Rosane Doré Lefebvre (Alfred-Pellan, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, on the Conservative's new security bill, Canadians have more questions than answers about whether these new powers are necessary, or even what they do.
floor: Mr. Speaker, on the Conservative's new security bill, Canadians have more questions than answers about whether these new powers are necessary, or even what they do.

Speaker: Hon. James Moore (Minister of Industry, CPC)
english: If the NDP does not understand that the Canadian Manufacturers & Exporters is the expert and that high taxes would kill jobs under the NDP's plan, then I guess we will all just have to live with our disappointment that the NDP just cannot learn.
floor: If the NDP does not understand that the Canadian Manufacturers & Exporters is the expert and that high taxes would kill jobs under the NDP's plan, then I guess we will all just have to live with our disappointment that the NDP just cannot learn.

Speaker: Mr. Peter Braid (Parliamentary Secretary for Infrastructure and Communities, CPC)
english: Public transit is an eligible category under every component of the plan.
floor: Public transit is an eligible category under every component of the plan.

Speaker: Mr. Guy Caron (Rimouski-Neigette—Témiscouata—Les Basques, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, over the past two years, the Conservatives have spent $1.6 million on promoting Canadian oil in the United States.
floor: Monsieur le Président, au cours des deux dernières années, les conservateurs ont dépensé 1,6 million de dollars pour faire la promotion du pétrole canadien aux États-Unis.

Speaker: M. Emmanuel Dubourg (Bourassa, Lib.)
english: Instead of governing, are the Conservatives already campaigning?
floor: Au lieu de gouverner, les conservateurs sont-ils déjà en campagne électorale?

Speaker: Ms. Niki Ashton (Churchill, NDP)
english: It is vital to the healing of first nations, Metis, and Inuit people in Ottawa who are at risk or in transition.
floor: It is vital to the healing of first nations, Métis, and Inuit people in Ottawa who are at risk or in transition.

Speaker: Ms. Niki Ashton (Churchill, NDP)
english: Will the minister intervene to reinstate the funding for the Odawa centre?
floor: Will the minister intervene to reinstate the funding for the Odawa centre?

Speaker: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development, CPC)
english: For the member's information, the aboriginal urban strategy has been revamped and funding has been increased to communities all across Canada.
floor: For the member's information, the aboriginal urban strategy has been revamped and funding has been increased to communities all across Canada.

Speaker: Hon. Hedy Fry (Vancouver Centre, Lib.)
english: Public health officers, health authorities, and municipalities have raised concerns with the minister.
floor: Public health officers, health authorities, and municipalities have raised concerns with the minister.

Speaker: Hon. Thomas Mulcair (Leader of the Opposition, NDP)
english: Mr. Speaker, a report has confirmed that the Canadian Forces are now involved in combat, despite the Prime Minister's formal commitment last fall that our soldiers would not be on the front lines.
floor: Monsieur le Président, un rapport confirme que les Forces canadiennes sont désormais impliquées dans les combats, et ce, malgré les promesses formelles du premier ministre cet automne disant qu'elles ne seraient pas au front.

Speaker: Hon. Thomas Mulcair (Leader of the Opposition, NDP)
english: They are not allowed to accompany Iraqi forces to the front lines.
floor: They are not allowed to accompany Iraqi forces to the front lines.

Speaker: Hon. Thomas Mulcair (Leader of the Opposition, NDP)
english: It is a simple question.
floor: It is a simple question.

Speaker: Right Hon. Stephen Harper (Prime Minister, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, obviously I do not know the facts of this particular case, but whenever we lose a serving military officer or a former military member, it is a terrible thing, and our condolences go out to that family.
floor: Mr. Speaker, obviously I do not know the facts of this particular case, but whenever we lose a serving military officer or a former military member, it is a terrible thing, and our condolences go out to that family.

Speaker: Mr. Justin Trudeau (Papineau, Lib.)
english: Mr. Speaker, once again, with income splitting, the government will favour Canadians who earn over $233,000 per year.
floor: Monsieur le Président, encore une fois, avec le fractionnement du revenu, le gouvernement favorisera ceux qui gagnent plus de 233 000 $ par année.

Speaker: Mr. Justin Trudeau (Papineau, Lib.)
english: Will the Prime Minister live up to our sacred obligation, end this court battle, and start giving our veterans the help they deserve?
floor: Will the Prime Minister live up to our sacred obligation, end this court battle, and start giving our veterans the help they deserve?

Speaker: Hon. James Moore (Minister of Industry, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, we have a number of policies, investments and approaches to stimulate the economy and create jobs in the manufacturing sector.
floor: Monsieur le Président, nous avons plusieurs politiques, investissements et approches pour stimuler l'économie et créer des emplois dans le secteur manufacturier.

Speaker: Mr. Matthew Dubé (Chambly—Borduas, NDP)
english: We need to improve this process.
floor: Améliorons enfin ce processus.

Speaker: Mr. Chris Warkentin (Peace River, CPC)
english: Mr. Speaker, today we woke up to the horrendous news that Israel has once again been the target of terrorist attacks.
floor: Mr. Speaker, today we woke up to the horrendous news that Israel has once again been the target of terrorist attacks.

Speaker: Hon. Rob Nicholson (Minister of National Defence, CPC)
english: The Liberals, in voting against all of these measures, probably missed all of this, but we are taking on an advise and assist role on the ground with the Iraqis, and we are conducting air strikes with our allies out of Kuwait.
floor: The Liberals, in voting against all of these measures, probably missed all of this, but we are taking on an advise and assist role on the ground with the Iraqis, and we are conducting air strikes with our allies out of Kuwait.
